Name: Duck Duck 1-2-3
Description:
Welcome to Duck Duck 1-2-3, where you move Mama duck around the park, pick up all the baby ducklings and take them to a party in the pond!

This game is one in the latest wave of games by Cranium for preschoolers. These games intend to bring parents and their little ones together by participating in a fun and interactive setting.
The three games in the trilogy (Puppy Pals Bingo, Duck Duck 1-2-3 and Polar Bear A-B-C) are a fun way for your preschooler to learn about matching shapes and patterns, simple counting and spelling.

In Duck Duck 1-2-3, players must spin a spinner to move their Mama ducks around the various parts of the pond to pick up their 3 ducklings. You must count your way along the lily pads to the island in the center where all the ducks are having a party!

Name: Mardi Gras
Description:
This is a non-partnership precise-bid trick-taking game with a few twists.

The deck has five suits (1-King), with  Mardi-Gras  - related symbols: Masks, Crowns, Doubloon, Fleur de Lis, and Beads -- Masks are always trump.  Plus there is one Mardi Gras card, which counts as the highest trump; and two FATuesday cards, which can always be played and count as the lowest cards (if led, a suit is declared).  The 68 cards deal evenly with 4 players; with other numbers, leave out enough "1" cards so it goes evenly.

Each player bids the number of tricks he'll take -- the goal is to take exactly that many.  If you make your bid you get 10 points per trick (a successful bid of 0 earns 10).  If you go over, you get 1 point per trick taken; if under, you lose 10 points times your bid.  Play until a pre-assigned total, such as 200 point.

The advanced Challenge game has extra rules: The Mardi Gras card can be declared when played as the highest or lowest trump; when led, each player must play their highest trump in hand.  Bids are in secret, written down and revealed simultaneously.  A Nil bid goes for 0 tricks and earns or loses 50 points.  Finally, after the bids each player has a chance to double their own bid, to double the points at stake, except you also lose if you go over your bid.

Name: Samba
Description:
This is a popular variation of Canasta invented during its craze of the 1940's and 50's.  As the official rules from the Association of American Playing Card Manufacturers says, "It offers wider melding opportunities than regular Canasta played with two packs, and is preferred by many players on that account."

The major differences are: 
- Three packs are used rather than two.
- Sequences of cards are allowed as valid melds (in addition to sets of the same rank).
- Fifteen cards are dealt, instead of 11.
- Two cards are drawn at a time, rather than one.

There are dedicated Samba decks published, some of which include the cards' scoring values on them.

Name: Number Up
Description:
This game appears to be a fusion of Yahtzee and Scrabble, from the Lowe's the original publisher of Yahtzee Lowe's.

The object of the game is to roll the included wooden 6 sided dice with non-traditional numbering building sequences that players place on the board for scoring all while under time pressure from the included sand timer.  The board looks remarkably similar to a small Scrabble board, with double and triple score zones all in similar Scrabble colors.  The game board, also has a built in dice tray to accept keep rolling all these dice in one place.

Components:

12 Wooden six sided dice 
Blue plastic Game board with Dice tray
Dice Cup
Sand Timer
Instructions inside box cover.

Name: Armored Assault: Armored Reserves
Description:
A Vehicle Compendium for Armored Assault

This is a vehicle compendium designed to supplement Iron Crown Enterprises' Space Master series of games. It provides a number of vehicle designs which adventurers may meet in their travels, use, or wish to purchase. It includes the specs for:

2 Trucks
3 Carriers
6 MIRCs
3 Robotic Vehicles
2 Scouts
2 Armored Cars
2 Walkers
2 Jumptanks
3 Battle Tanks
2 Explorers
2 Dropships
1 Control Center
4 Armor Suits
6 Aerocraft
10 Scenarios

It also includes 180 new full-color counters.

Name: Spirit of '76
Description:
A trick-taking game based on winning electoral votes. There is a card for each state, with the value of their electoral vote total (as in 1976); they are split into two suits so the votes are split evenly.  (The cards also have common info about each state: capitol, population, area, state bird/tree/flower, etc.)  There is also a card for D.C., and 3 cards for territories.

Cards are dealt, players bid the number of votes they think they can win, winner declares trump suit, and trick-taking play commences, the vote for the cards acting as their rank.  The DC card is wild and captures its trick automatically; the territory cards void the tricks they are played on.  The declarer adds or subtracts their bid depending on if they won.  Winner is the first one to make 270 total votes.

Name: Repeat or You're Obsolete
Description: Players put their skills to the ultimate test as they make noises, act things out, create stories, make lists, and play with words in the hilarious, fast-paced game of memory madness.

Name: Hooked
Description:
A fishing game for 2-3 players Ages 4 and up.  Switch it on and use the rods to catch the fish.

Game 1:
Each player selects a coloured rod.  The first player to catch all their own fish is the winner.

Game 2:
Stick the numbered score labels on the underside of the fish.  Catch fish of any colour.  When all fish have been caught, the player with the highest score is the winner.

Name: Dominion: Black Market Promo Card
Description:
Revised text (2017):

Black Market (Action - Cost 3 [coin])

Reveal the top 3 cards of the Black Market deck. Play any number of Treasures from your hand. You may buy one of the revealed Cards.  Put the rest on the bottom of the Black Market deck in any order.

Setup: Make a Black Market deck out of different unused Kingdom cards.



Original Text:Black Market (Action - Cost 3 [coin])

Reveal the top 3 cards of the Black Market deck. You may buy one of them immediately.  Put the un-bought cards on the bottom of the Black Market deck in any order.

(Before the game, make a Black Market deck out of one copy of each Kingdom card not in the supply.)

Name: Gimme
Description: An exciting and thrilling combination of the nations most popular card games Poker and Michigan Rummy for both young and old

Name: Card Spin
Description:
This game maps traditional playing cards onto the magnetic wheels also found in [GAMEID=10965].

From the instructions: "Each of the 10 wheels contain a different combination of ten 'cards' for a total of 100 card faces.  Wheels can be separated from each other and played individually, or snapped together magnetically in 'hands'.  Millions of card combinations are possible.

"Using the magic CARD SPIN Wheels is fun and adds a new element of chance to games.  Get the feel of the wheels.  Most hands are played with 5 or less wheels.  Rotate and arrange them to form winning combinations."

Instructions are included for versions of Rummy, Black Jack, Poker, War, and a sort of Crazy Eights.

Name: Sea Command
Description: Subtitled: Present Day Naval-Air and Anti-Submarine Warfare. Labeled as "The supplement to Warship Commander", this 62 page rulebook states that this volume is actually part 2 of the complete rules, covering all aspects of naval-air and anti-submarine warfare. It also includes updates to the Warship Commander rules and optional rules for a three player game, long distance aircraft operations, and a dozen other minor optional rules.

Name: Mious 1943
Description:
The 30th July 1943, the 2nd SS PZ launched an attack against the Southern Soviet front elements base on the Mious.

This is a mini-game published in VaeVictis #85. It has 50 counters, 2 pages rules and a one page map.

Each turn equals 3 hours.
Each hex equals 1 km.
Units are regiments, battalions and companies.

Name: Starship
Description: This 23 page rule book is a supplement to Star War 2250 A.D. It adds a starship design system, rule changes, new weapons, and technology levels.

Name: Lightning Strike Companion
Description:
Lightning Strike Companion is an 80 page supplement to Lightning Strike 2nd Edition, adding more advanced rules, an expanded campaign game, and fleet lists for smaller and non-aligned forces.

Expands:

    Lightning Strike

Name: Adventures of Pinocchio: An Electric Game
Description:
A Spin-and-Move game with an 'electric' element.  Players take turns flicking a spinner attached to the board and moving their wire prod.  If the contact makes the whales eye light up, the player reads a fact about the story of Pinocchio from an enclosed booklet and then advances or retreats a set number of spaces per the booklet.

A 'Wiry Dan' game published by Harett-Gilmar, Inc.  Circa 1950's according to the book American Games by Alex Malloy.

Name: Googly Moogly
Description:
"The dice game with the magic dots"

This simple game's theme is from the "Maggie and the Ferocious Beast" franchise.

It is meant for 1-4 players from Ages 3 1/2 to 6.

It involves rolling a special dice: two sides have a 1 and get the roller one dot from the middle of the table; two sides have a 2 and get two dots; one side is a hat that gets a dot from another player; one side is a hat which loses a dot to the player on the left.

The winner is the first player to fill his or her board's monster with dots.

Ravensburger Game no. 23 137 9

Name: Kim Color
Description:
A pure memory game for kids: players have 45 seconds to memorize the pattern of symbols shown on a card, then to reconstruct it upon a 25 squares grid by arranging tiles.

The game board consists of a wooden frame with five poles, each pole showing five wooden cubes (so a 5 x 5 grid is formed). Each of the four cube sides that can be on top (all except the two with the pole running through it) has a symbol (one of five).

The cubes are randomly set up, then a player (or a team of players) has a minute to look at the pattern. The grid is then covered and the player(s) have to reproduce the pattern with wooden chips that have to be placed in the same order as seen. The player(s) with the best memory is/are the winner.

Name: Lucky Luke et la bataille contre les Dalton
Description:
The game is played with 78 special cards.

The goal is to capture the four Dalton, which can be done each time a Dalton card appears by playing a “Lucky Luke” or a “Rantanplan” card of same value. A “Lucky luke” card of value 12 allows the player to choose several Dalton cards of with a total value of 12.

Name: Le magistral
Description:
Based upon the tv broadcast of the same name. More than 10000 questions about history, geography, science, nature, sports, voices, famous people, culture, arts… Each card lists 10 questions of increasing difficulty.

There are four different rules based upon these difficulties. In order to win, players must either collect a card from each theme, or a maximum score (harder questions being of greater scoring value).

Name: Politico
Description:
Each player tries to be elected prime minister. Each round allows players to earn marks, if different players collaborate into a government, every player wins marks.

Votes depends upon how many deputies represents each political party, so the scoring sheets takes tracks both of the number of deputies and of the marks of each player.

There are different attacking or defending ways to push someone into the government, sometimes with the intention of making him fall later!

Name: Roll 'n Multiply
Description:
The Game of Multiplication, Strategy and Fun!

Roll ’n Multiply, the exciting multiplication game, assists younger students in basic multiplication skills and challenges players proficient in multiplication. The game’s unique 10-sided dice enable students to multiply as high as 100. Simply roll the die, and multiply the numbers together. Corresponding game pieces are then strategically placed on the playing board.

Because Roll ’n Multiply encourages cooperative play, opponents assist each other in multiplying the numbers, and the enclosed multiplication table confirms the answer. Four in a row wins the game- but watch out! Your playing piece may be captured and then flipped to the opponent’s side! For beginning players, winning depends on luck and strategy, not on multiplication ability. Advanced students challenge their opponent’s multiplication and strategy skills or assist novice players with multiplication.

Name: Stonehenge: Bonusspiele #1
Description:
This supplemental anthology of games for the Stonehenge game system was given to anyone who bought Stonehenge: An Anthology Board Game at SPIEL 2007.  It contains the rules for the following five games:


     Der hohe Rat (political game) by Volker Hesselmann, for 2 or 4 players (2 vs. 2): The druids have to vote for or against a motion. Each player tries to convince his neighbor in the council. The aim is to get the majority within the council.
     Erbaut Stonehenge (construction game) by Dustin D. Trammell, for 3 to 4 players: All players are building Stonehenge. Each player represents a single cult and tries to build the most magnificent elements and beat the other cults by reputation.
     Rollende Steine (dexterity game) by Tyler Tinsley, for 1 to 5 players: Each player represents a celtic giant. The giants play their favorite game: Rolling stones through the triliths. 8 triliths compositions are proposed in the rules, others can be invented by the players. The player win or lose togehter.
     Trilithen Knallen (carambolage racing game) by Nicolas and Volker Hesselmann for 2 to 5 players: During the annual carambolage race, a bunch of manic druids on their triliths try to ram the others by remembering the hidden cards. The last one on the course wins the race.
     Opferroulette (luck game) by Jason Bulmahn for 2 to 5 players: The players are gods and try to promote their favorite to become the high priest. To do so, they need to avoid the oblation of their priest while destroying the other ones during the ancestral stone-sphere game.


A PDF of Bonusspiele #1 can be acquired here (German).

Name: Explore! Photo Safari
Description:
The fastest one wins! With the help of clues, you must be the frist player to photograph the animals on the card. Take a chance! Play it Fast! Place your pawn on the animal and photograph it. With explore photo safari you and your children will be captivated by geography.

This game includes an oversized boardgame map of the world 4 pawns for 2 to 4 players, and 112 animal cards with 336 clues to play three different ways. For ages 4 and up: Visual Clues; For Ages 7 and up: Descriptive clues; for Ages 9 and up: Geographic Clues.

Name: Ion Glory's Destroyer
Description: Ion Glory's Destroyer is a supplement to Ion Glory adding two new ship types, frigate and destroyer, a new optional rule, more ship and weapon cards, and new action cards. Like the original game, components are supplied uncut on card stock.

Name: Ion Glory's Fleet
Description: Ion Glory's Fleet is a supplement to Ion Glory adding new ship types (battleship, escort, corvette, support, tug, research, orbital base, raider, drone tug, minesweeper, troop carrier, pocket battleship), new weapons, new rules, more ship cards, and a complete redesigned set of weapon cards. Like the original game, components are supplied uncut on card stock.

Name: Wheels of Time
Description:
In this free print-and-play game, you'll try to complete your city with walls, roads, and buildings. By turning wheels, you can form links that provide resources and developments or allow you to steal from the other player. If you're not careful, though, you may help your opponent or suffer disaster.

Wheels of Time is a short development game that uses a spatial mechanism. With just four printable wheels, one six-sided die, and a pencil and paper (or the optional player aids), it is quick and easy to put together. Options are included for both solitaire and 2-player games.

Name: Tactilo Loto
Description:
A game for children Ages 3+ and up in which players spin a well with six different textures embedded in it.  Players then search for the similar texture on an animal card in an opaque bag.

If you find the right kind of animal you keep the card, otherwise you return it.

The game ends when the bag is empty.  The player with the most cards wins!

From the box cover:

A TACTILE DISCOVERY GAME.
Find a cuddly bear, a frizzy sheep or even a rough lizard by touch...  that is the challenge launched by the tactilo loto arrow!

Name: Prophecy of War
Description: A set of 1/300th scale (6mm) generic science fiction land warfare miniatures rules designed to quickly handle around 100 models in a 4' by 6' table space.

Name: Democracy: The Board Game
Description:
Playing for votes, players represent a continent of the world, and must try to develop their infrastructure (Housing, Education, Health, Military etc.).  Votes mean power and the ability to develop.

Also in playing the game is the Dictator, who starts the game with more power and who is trying to take over the world.

Players will also get caught up in The Economy, Climate Change, Human Rights etc. which can mean gaining or losing votes.

The game is turn based by throwing dice, and is a mixture of luck and strategy.

Name: Quiz Wiz
Description:
From the Pamphlet:

QUIZ WIZ is the computerized question and answer game that challenges you with 1,001 questions on topics like movies, TV, sports, trivia, and much more! And it's easy to use. Choose a question from the quiz book, then enter an answer from the multiple choices provided. Electronic lights and sounds tell you how you scored. If you're right, you get the green light and "beep". If you're wrong, you get the red light and "buzz". See how many questions you can answer!

QUIZ WIZ includes the Quiz Wiz computer, a programmed cartridge and a quiz book of 1,001 questions - all stylishly packed in a convenient vinyl case. Requires one 9 volt battery or Coleco Battery Eliminator / AC Adapter (neither included). U.S. Patent #4,164,078 and Patent Pending.

Name: Summoner Trinity
Description:
This is a fantasy themed CCG from Thailand.

The game has 3 card types that can be separated by their backside: Seal cards (blue with star), Mystic cards (red with sun) and HP cards (white with moon).

The game has similar rules to Summoner Master but shorter game. The difference between this game and Summoner Master is HP mechanic and upgrade mechanic of each Seal cards (Character cards) and the deck construction size.

This CCG card size is half from Summoner Master.

This game has 3 variants.

     Single game - 15 Mystic cards + 15 HP cards
     Buddy game - 20 Mystic cards + 40 HP cards
     Trinity game - 30 Mystic cards + 60 HP cards


The cards and rules are only available in Thai.

Modified from

     Summoner Master

Name: Zurero
Description:
This game is an interesting variation of Go-Moku, in which players "slide" stones along the board lines from the edge of the board till the "sliding" stone is stopped by another stone on the board.

The intriguing feature of the game is that the "sliding" stone pushes the "stopping" stone if there is an empty space behind it.

Name: Shintai
Description:
A variant of Go-Moku aimed at eliminating the first-player advantage.
Every fifth move, instead of placing a stone, the player relocates one of their stones that is already on the board.

Name: TriGo
Description:
TriGo is a variant of Go game that is played on a hexagonal board and uses stone placement mechanism taken from Connect6. It means that the first player places a single stone and every subsequent move players places two stones per turn.

Placing two stones per turn makes game more dynamic and hexagonal shape of the board makes strategies and tactics different from the Go (i.e. in TriGo two "eyes" are not enough for protecting a group of stones).

Name: Naruto Ninja Battleground
Description: Naruto, Sasuke and Kakashi Battle Itachi, Gaara, and Orochimaru in the Forrest of Death. Each player takes control of a three ninja team in an epic fight. The Object of the game is to either eliminate the opponents team OR be in control of both Hidden Scrolls!

Name: American Girl Treasures Game
Description:
Collect keepsakes from the American Girl stories!

Go on a journey with the American Girls to collect their favorite things! Each player helps one of the American Girls travel to shops and trade for treasures from her stories. Along the way, players will remember exciting times in the stories... and become part of the American Girl adventure!

Name: Scene It? Disney Super Game Pack
Description: The Disney Scene It DVD Game is the perfect game for any Disney fan! The Scene It Disney Super Game Pack is loaded with all new movie clips, trivia questions and puzzlers from The Incredibles, Chicken Little and all your favorite Disney movies. This game pack lets you relive all the fun and excitement of unforgettable Disney movie moments, from swimming with sea turtles in the East Australian Current to battling the evil Syndrome on his secret island base. Whether you play it by itself or add it to your existing Scene It? games, Scene It? Disney Super Game Pack is destined to be a family game night favorite. This Disney Scene It? Game features clips from Toy Story 2, Finding Nemo, The Incredibles, and more of your favorite Disney movies! You can add new Disney magic to any Scene It? game with more clips, trivia cards and tokens!

Name: Upstacks
Description:
The sky-high, dice-stacking game!

Do you have luck, skill and a steady hand? UPSTACKS is the exciting new game from GAMEFORCE Studios that provides a fun game experience for 2-4 players.

Roll the dice! Every dice counts when its time to add up the points. Be the first to reach the final score and win the game, but beware of the penalty dice as your opponent pushes you to go too far. How high can you stack YOUR tower?

Name: B'Maso!: The Winds of Change – Wars in Africa
Description:
From the Mau Mau in Kenya in the 1950's to South West Africa in the 1980's, B'Maso is our latest supplement for BOTH I Ain't Been Shot, Mum and Troops, Weapons & Tactics covering the Winds of Change wars in Africa.

Containing full rule amendments, a history of counter-insurgency warfare in Africa, a look at all the major conflicts, along with data on organizing your forces and gaming this interesting period. B'Maso! Covers the Mau Mau in Kenya in the 1950s, Katanga and the Congo in the 1960s, Biafra and Nigeria, Rhodesia, the Portuguese Wars in Mozambique, Guinea Bissau and Angola, and the border war in South West Africa.

One hundred and thirty four pages long this supplement also contains full colour maps, scenarios and everything you need to get started gaming in Africa.

Name: Panzer Grenadier: Hopeless, But Not Serious – The Austrian Federal Army, 1934-1938
Description:
Hopeless, But Not Serious is a supplement for the Panzer Grenadier system based on the actual actions of the Austrian Army against Socialist and Nazi militias in 1934, and potential battles foreseen by the Jansa Plan in 1938. This module is not playable by itself, but requires ownership of our Eastern Front, Road to Berlin, Battle of the Bulge, Elsenborn Ridge and Cassino '44 games and our Edelweiss and Sinister Forces supplements to enjoy all of the scenarios. There are 16 scenarios, two each from the Austrian Civil War and Nazi Uprising of 1934, one based on the only actual combat between German and Austrian units in 1938, and the other 10 drawn from potential battles considered by the Austrian General Staff that did not actually occur.

Hopeless, But Not Serious is sold via PDF download as well as in a professionally published edition with mounted, die-cut counters.

Name: De Kolonisten van Catan: De drie Handelsteden van Noord-Nederland
Description:
A special board for CATAN, depicting the three northern provinces of The Netherlands. The capitals of the provinces are trade cities (handelsteden), and offer various bonuses: trade as if they are 3:1 or 2:1 harbor, or a wildcard production tile, depending on the precise location of your village/city.
Instead of mountains, on this map swamps produce ore (historically correct!); there are no mountains in this part of the country.

Part of the Catan Series.

Name: Warlands: Full Throttle Vehicular Combat!
Description:
"No one can seem to remember exactly how it started or indeed how it ended. But it did…

Now decades after the last war, mankind fights for survival on the battlefields of a post-apocalyptic earth. WARLANDS pits the last human survivors against each other and the unnatural horrors that breed in the wastelands and dead cities. Strap yourself in for high octane action from small scale skirmishes to epic battles, The WARLANDS sing with the screams of the dying and the roar of machines…

WARLANDS is a turbo-charged miniature game of cinematic combat set in the ruins of a post-apocalyptic earth. Where the last remnants of Man battle for supremacy and resources against mutants, the dead and each other! Where the warriors of the 
wastelands want but one thing, the black gold, the guzzoline."

Warlands is a miniatures wargame involving vehicular combat in a post-apocalyptic (Road Warrior, Deathrace, Doomsday, etc. inspired) setting.  Players can build forces of weaponized cars, trucks, dune-buggies, bikes, walkers, as well as foot infantry.

Gameplay is quick and is alternating activation.  Players roll for initiative, and each activates a model, based on speed, where they move, shoot, accelerate, decelerate and perform special actions (emergency braking, bootlegger reverse, un-jam weapon, etc).  Once all activations have been performed the turn ends.

Each vehicle type (Car, Truck, Buggie, Semi, Walker, etc) has their own special abilities and base attributes.  These include their speed and maneuverability, ability to absorb damage, and off-road capabilities.

Shooting involves die rolling, where shooter must roll higher than a fixed target value, based on the target's current speed (the faster it's going, the harder it is to hit).  Models in very close range get extra bonuses to hit.  Shooting has critical success / failure mechanisms, where a success would be an auto hit and a failure results in a weapons jam.

Damage is modified by the target's armor and the weapons armor penetration value.  This will determine the target value for the dice rolled to damage the target.  Each target has a number of hit points.  Critical damage rolls result in special damage to a vehicle that can range from degrading its performance to outright destroying it in a ball of fire.

Movement has compulsory movement to simulate momentum, and varies by the model type and current speed.  Each model has a number of 45 degree turns it's allowed within a turn and how far it must move in a straight line before it can turn again.  Special Maneuvers require a die roll to beat a target value, the roll is modified by the driver's skill, current vehicle speed and available turns the vehicle has.  Success generally means the vehicle can turn or maneuver any way it wants, failure results in random movement or total wipe-out of vehicle.

The scale is 20mm and is compatible with most die-cast toy cars (Matchbox, Hotwheels, etc.).  The line will include not only vehicles but blister packs of weapons and customization bitz to upgrade existing toy cars.  At first this seems odd for a miniatures wargaming scale, but the movement works well within a 4x4 table and being able to customize toy cars will be a hobby in itself.

Name: Nosh
Description: This card game introduces and encourages healthy eating. Be the first to collect your 5-a-day fruit and vegetables in this memory game that includes healthy and not so healthy every day foods. Cartoon style food ranges from strawberries and pineapple to chocolate and chips (French Fries for Americans).

Name: Yin-Yang
Description:
Yin-Yang is a two player game of claiming territory. It is played on a checkered board with dark and light stones. The board starts with some stones on it, then players take turns moving and adding stones until no more moves are possible.

Player One tries to have stones on squares of matching color (dark on dark or light on light), and Player Two tries to have stones on squares of contrasting color (dark on light or light on dark). At the end of the game, count up each player's score. Player One scores one point for each stone that is on a square of the same color, and Player Two gets one point for each stone that is on a square of the opposite color. No one gets points for unoccupied squares.

The player with the higher score wins the game. If scores are tied, Player Two wins the game.

An entry into the About.com: 2004 Shared Pieces Game Design Competition.

Name: Yangsh
Description: In Yangsh two players try to make rows of 5 markers by flipping them to their own color. Markers can be flipped by jumping over them with pawns, moving along straight lines in 8 directions. Pawns can only land on an empty field. Markers are placed when taking off form an empty field. When you succeed in making 5-in-a-row, you must take the row and one of your pawns off the board, making it harder for you to make the next 5-in-a-row. First player to play 3 pawns off the board wins.

Name: Up and Over
Description:
A quick card game of summing and limits for two to five players.

Object: To gather tricks by making the sum of the cards in play equal 21, or by forcing the player to your left to cause the sum of the cards to exceed 21.

You Need:

* A standard poker deck (jokers optional).
    * Paper and pencil to tally tricks.

This is a game that is similar to Cribbage. Each player has a hand of five cards. On your turn, you play a card to the table, adding its value to the previously played cards until the value of the played cards equal or exceed 21. If the value of the cards played equals 21, you take the trick. If the value exceeds 21, the player to your right takes the trick (for forcing you to go up and over 21.) The value of most cards is equal to its face value, but aces and face cards have different values, including negative values. The first player to win 21 tricks is the winner.

Name: Toy Train
Description:
Players take turns adding letter cars to a train, working together to form a word. The goal of the Engine-Driver is to form the longest word he can; on the other hand, the goal of the Braker is to form the shortest word he can. The longer the word, the farther the Engine-Driver (whose turn it is) will advance along the scoring track.

This game appeared in issue 15 of GiocAreA Online.

Name: Timber Wars
Description:
This is a basic wargame that uses bits of wood as units. Each group is marked with a group tag. The game uses a point system based on gold pieces -- each unit is worth a certain number of gold pieces and are purchased at the beginning of the game. The players alternate placing terrain, structures, and siege engines. Once this is completed, the players fight it out to see who is victorious! Players can also come up with scenarios if they wish.

Available from http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

Name: Marea
Description:
The idea behind The Tide is the cooperation between two designers. An author from daVinci (Silvano Sorrentino, "Dancing Dice", "Ostrakon" among others) has written the first page of these rules, while an author from Red Omega Studio (Piero Cioni, "Crazy Rally", "Tortuga"), has completed the work. Successful experiment? You call it!

The playing area is made up of a 6 x 6 area of tiles (the extra 36 tiles are placed in 6 piles of 6 tiles each at the top of the paying area, which represent the tide.) Each player controls 4 pawns, representing friends who are collecting shells & cleaning up trash at a beach. On his turn, each player can do one of the following: move one of his friends, collect ONE seashell, or collect one OR MORE pieces of rubbish. Each time a tile is removed, it is replaced by a tile from the tide.

The game ends as soon as one of the following conditions is met: one of the players reaches 10 points: that player is the winner, OR one of the column runs out of tiles (no tiles in the column, no tiles in the relevant pile); the winner is the player with the most points. In case of a tie, the winner among tied players is the one with the most tiles

(Note: the link on the game's website to the pieces is broken. However, you can get the components from the Italian edition -- here's the link to the archive: http://www.davincigames.it/giocarea/archivio/giocarea11.zip. The components are language-independent.)

This game appeared in issue #11 of GiocAreA Online.

Name: The Things
Description:
The Things is a game for three or (ideally) more players, and simulates the paranoid members of an antarctic research facility being overrun by - or conquering - an invasive shape-shifting, human-killing alien. A standard deck of cards is used, with the different cards having different abilities. Players are either Things or Humans.

A random player is chosen to start, and turns progress in alphabetic or clockwise order. On each of their turns, a player may choose either to Search (draw a single card from the draw pile which they may or may not be able to keep), Converse (trade with other players), perform a Blood Test (force others to reveal cards)or Attack.

Game End and Winning:
For Humans: A Human player may, at any time, decide that the camp has been cleansed and that it's safe to radio for a rescue plane. That player reveals their hand, and declares that the game is over. All other players then reveal their hands. If any Things are shown to be still alive, then they are unleashed upon civilization and win the game. If only Humans remain, however, then the Thing has been vanquished and the Humans win the game.
For Things: A Thing player may, at any time, decide that the camp has been cleansed and that it's safe to build a two-seater flying saucer and head for civilization. That player reveals their hand, and declares that the game is over. All other players then reveal their hands. If any Humans are shown to be still alive, then they manage to sabotage the saucer and destroy the Things in the process. If only Things remain, however, then they merge into a single two-seater blob and fly off to conquer the world.

Name: Takat
Description:
The board is made up of 7 circles arranged in a hexagonal grid making up a large hexagon. Every other circle on the outer ring is coloured red. Although the board can be made up of Hexagons instead.

The white player must get 1 stack of six. The stack can be made up of black pieces as well as white pieces, or can be made up of just one colour. Even if the black player makes the stack, it still counts.

If white immobilizes black, then white wins. Black must immobilize white.

An entry into the About.com: 2002 Unequal Forces Game Design Competition.

Name: Axis & Allies: War at Sea – Flank Speed Booster Pack
Description:
From the Avalon Hill website:

All hands on deck for the second expansion to the War at Sea naval miniatures game. Flank Speed will contain 40 authentically detailed miniatures that war gamers, WWII enthusiasts, and collectors can use to assemble fleets with which to do battle on the seas of World War II. Battleships, cruisers, submarines and aircraft will help you bring the battle to your opponent. Flank Speed will let players add to their existing navies to recreate historical battles that rage across massive 30×40 battle maps.

Flank Speed vessels include:

Unique ships such as the Schleswig-Holstein, USS Arizona, "Jill" Torpedo Bomber, and the Russian Battleship October Revolution feature their distinctive markings and camouflage. 
Prepainted, durable plastic assembled and ready to play, right out of the box. 
Abilities and statistics of units based on historical performance in battle. 
Accuracy and detail of miniatures attracts collectors and WWII enthusiasts.

This game expands Axis & Allies Naval Miniatures: War at Sea (base game) and Axis & Allies: War at Sea Task Force (first expansion).  It can also be played on its own as well.

Name: Trivial Pursuit Singles: Entertainment
Description:
600 questions about movies, music, & more plus a special die in a small, wedge-shaped storage container.

The game does not feature a game board, and thus, there is no roll-and-move mechanic. Instead, players roll the color-coded die, and answers a question matching the color rolled. If a player correctly answers a question, he may "go for a wedge" by answering another question in the same category. If he does so, he keeps that card. If the player answers a question incorrectly, it is the next player's turn. Play ends when a player has collected six cards/correctly answered 12 questions.

Name: Trivial Pursuit Singles: R & R
Description: 600 questions about things you do while you're just kickin' back in a wedge-shaped storage container.

Name: Trivial Pursuit Singles: Music
Description: 600 questions about music and the people who make it (and more) in a wedge-shaped storage container.

Name: Trivial Pursuit Singles: Sports & Games
Description: 600 questions about sports, computer games, and board games in a wedge-shaped storage container.

Name: Alarm für Cobra 11: Das Brettspiel
Description:
Get into your car, catch the runaway criminals and be the first to return to the Motorway Police District.

This is the official game of the 1996 German TV serial "Alarm für Cobra 11 - Die Autobahnpolizei" (Alarm for Cobra 11 - The Motorway Police).

Contents of the box:
- 30 Wanted cards
- 19 Joker cards
- 6 reward cards
- 1 cardboard map
- 6 stand up cars
- 1 rulebook
- 3 dice

Name: Folly
Description:
A childrens' card game.  The object is to be the first to get rid of all your cards.

The dealer shuffles the pack and deals the required number of cards to each player.  He spreads out the "spare" cards, face up, in the centre of the table.  On their turn a player turns up his top card and tries to place it on any of the "spare" cards in ascending or descending order.  If he can't follow the sequence they place the card face up next to his own pile. Other players who can't play a card on the "spare" cards can instead play a card in seqence onto any of the other player's face-up cards.  If they can't, they put the card in their own face-up pile.

If a player places a card incorrectly the other players shout "Folly" and they each give you a card from their face-down piles to add to your pile.  When your face-down pile runs out, turn your face-up pile face-down and carry on.  The first player to get rid of all his cards wins.

Name: Beggar My Neighbour
Description: Each player starts with a face-down deck of cards.  In turn each player places their top card in the middle of the table.  When a "Put" card is played, the next player has to put down the number of cards required.  If they play a "Put" card, then their turn ends and the next player goes.  If no "Put" card turns up in the cards put down, the player who laid the last "Put" card gets all the cards from the centre of the table.  A player who runs out of cards is out of the game.  The last player left in the game is the winner.

Name: Battlestations: Fleet Admiral
Description:
On the heels of the very successful Battlestations Adventure Game, comes a new stand alone game in the Battlestations Universe. Instead of controlling one crew member in adventure style missions you’ll be able to play Battlestations: Fleet Actions taking charge of multiple ships and crews. No referee is needed as players battle each other for mission objectives, all the while gaining prestige, leveling up their crews with new ship wide special abilities.

Featured is a new sleek rule set that has all the familiar Battlestations feel, but built for quicker and faster resolution on a massive scale. The familiar power levels in the ships are there with a few minor tweaks. For starters, all ships have unlimited helm power allowing them to perform a number of actions a phase only limited by the number of pilots. As a drawback however, any ship that fails in a piloting maneuver loses the rest of it’s actions! Make sure those pilots go last! If you have to turn the ship to fire weapons make sure you make your skill check! Guns and shields work a little differently. The size of your ship determines the power that both guns and shields can have combined. It’s up to the player to decide how that power is split. So a size 9 ship has 9 points of power to split between guns and shields. Unlike Battlestations energy levels never drop and there’s no more power generation before a round begins. This means there’s only ever two times during the course of the game that you have to adjust power levels; if your engines go down or if you transfer power. No more power booking keeping between rounds.

Another new game mechanic is automatic actions. By activating crew some actions happen automatically.

Name: Geometrie-Piraten
Description:
Wow, the Geometry Pirates have discovered the hexagonal island where the notorious pirate Geometrikus has buried his treasure: golden spheres, glittering pyramids and much more. The pirates equipped with the square treasure card and the round compass go on the exciting treasure hunt. The game collection acquaints 1-4 pirates with geometric shapes and solids and trains spatial perception.

Includes guide to geometry.

Name: The Red White & Blue Game
Description: Game comes with a cloth game board, wooden squares and instructions in a heavy drawstring bag. Instructions say that the game is a game of logic and strategy for 2 to 4 people. The game is published by Scuda games of Boston.

Name: My Century
Description:
"A fun and exciting card game for kids and adults.  Over 100 cards that will keep memories of the 20th Century alive forever."

This unique deck has one card for each year from 1900 to 1998, with 5 events that happened that year, of all types: politics, sports, arts, inventions, etc.  There are also two 1999 cards, which act like wild cards, and four 2000 "Millenium Bug" cards, that are penalty cards.  The events each have an icon next to them to show a specific type: e.g. car, tennis player, Olympic rings, airplane, dollar sign, national flag, anchor, skull, etc.

There are rules to three games included.  In all of them, 10 cards are dealt to each player.

Century Classic is rummy-like: during their turn players draw, lay down melds, and discard.  Acceptable melds are: chains, 3 or more consecutive years; and matches: 3 or more that have the same event icon.  Players can also add to their previous melds, but not to others'.  When a player goes out, the others receive penalty points for what's left in their hand.  1999 cards are wild, and each player may use their birth year as a personal wild.  If you have a 2000 card may play it to the table and draw a replacement, taking up your whole turn; 2000's in your hand at the end add to your penalties.

Century Chain is Uno-like.  Players may play a card to the discard pile if it matches one of its icons, or is adjacent in year.  You may continue playing until you have nothing left.  If you have nothing to start, you may draw one card instead.  (1999s and 2000s are not included in this game.)  First player out of cards wins.

Century Face Off is a quasi-trick-taking game.  Players take turns playing a card to the center, and the one who played highest year takes the trick and leads to the next.  After the  10 cards are out, another 10 each (or however many are left) are dealt out.  Winner is the one who takes the most tricks.

Name: Flax Wild Animals
Description:
This game has 32 cards, each one representing a wild animal, with its name, a photograph, its habitat on a world map, and its value in 5 attributes: Size, Max Speed, Weight, Lifespan, and Danger Lever (the latter from 1 to 10).  There is also a card that just says "Flax".  And, two rules cards, and a title card that advertises the other versions: Flax Dinosaurs, and Flax Creatures of the Sea.

The Flax basic game is War-like.  All the cards are dealt out, and everyone looks at their top card.  The leading player picks one attribute and reads it out loud ("Okapi, Max Speed 35 mph".)  Everyone lays their card down and the card with the highest value in that attribute takes the lot; they go to the bottom of the winner's pile and he leads to the next trick.  The "Flax" card wins any trick but only may be used once.  The ultimate winner is the one who gets all the cards.

In the advanced game, players may look at their whole hand.  The leader chooses a card and a category, and only players who can beat it play to the middle.  The one who takes the trick leads next; but the game is won by the player who gets rid of all their cards first.

Name: Ranch Poker
Description:
Six cards are on the table. Players place bets on any of those (no tokens included for some reason) and roll three dice. The dice show on of the cards on each of their sides. If the cards you bet on are rolled, you get double your money back (one die), triple (two dice) or quadruple (all three dice). No goal is set, players just play as long as they want.
Was one of six little games in Piatnik's Texas Series in 1989.

Name: Rocky Hill
Description: Dice rolling game from the 1989 "Texas Series" published by Piatnik. Cards are placed on the table and form the "game board" Players move by combining the results of three dice in any way they see fit. In this way, they have to reach the exact number displayed on the next card of the route. You have to move to the 12th card and back in order to win the game.

Name: Turning Point: Fleet Action 2 Master Rules
Description:
From the back of the book:

"It seemed like only a few hours since the ENS Horan had backed out of the docking arm at Saturn Base. In truth, it has been several days, each intervening day filled with frantic activity as the crew prepared for the forthcoming battle. Now that battle was upon them. On the plot, two fleets could be seen closing in on one another. As the captain of the Horan watched, flanking forces detached themselves first from the European fleet, quickly followed by matching elements from the Union fleet. These elements would attempt to get around the heavy screens to the key units the escorts were protecting, the flagship and carriers. Soon the battle would truly be joined...
__________________________________________________________
What you hold in your hands is the Master Rules to the Fleet Action 2 combat system as well as the introductory information to the epic Turning Point Universe. These rules will allow you to fight massive battles involving potentially dozens of ships and even more fighters. If that's not enough, a highly robust and flexible design system will allow you to create the fleet of your dreams, whether it be from your favourite sci-fi epic or concocted from the deepest realms of your imagination.

Highlights of the Fleet Action 2 combat system...

     Modular design allows for easier expansion
     Combined arms mechanics encouraging the use of speciality ships such as escorts and carriers
     A myriad of types of weapons, each with their own strengths & weaknesses
     Streamlines combat rules allowing for large numbers of warships
     Simple but flexible fighter rules make large numbers of fighters simple to wield
     Powerful and robust custom design rules allow for the design of new weapons, ships, ammunition types and fighters"


Notes: This was published as a loose-leaf rulebook, pre-drilled for 4-ring binders. Originally intended to update Fleet Action in the Babylon 5 universe, Agents of Gaming lost the franchise during development, and so developed a setting of near-space settlement with various Earth nations and coalitions as the factions. An extensive line of miniatures was planned , but only the first few released before AoG ceased trading and closed it's doors for the final time.

Name: Sherbie vs The Silverfish
Description:
A light-hearted game of insecticide and stress for three to five players.

In the battle against vermin, you're either with Sherbie, or against her. Amass an army of silverfish and send them to torment Sherbie, or grab a paper towel and some bug spray and attempt to defeat the insectile menace. In the end, only one side can triumph.

Object: Be the player with the most silverfish in either your Sherbie stress pile or your squish pile.

Name: Robot Maze Race
Description:
Equipment: Each player needs a pencil and a sheet of paper marked as follows:


     Two 10x10 grids of squares, each grid should have rows labeled with A at the top through J at the bottom. Columns should be labeled with 1 at the left to 10 at the right. These grids will be referred to as your secret grid (the maze your opponent is trying to navigate) and your open grid (where you are trying to navigate the maze made by your opponent). You should not show your paper to your opponent at any time in the game.
     Space to write down your robot's program each turn.
     Space to mark your robot's health.


Robot Maze Race is a maze-solving game. Each player tries to program their robot to maneuver through a disorganized warehouse without bumping into too may crates or walls on the way.

An entry into the About.com: 2005 Deduction Game Design Competition.

Name: Reviser
Description:
This is a twist on the classic game Othello/Reversi. The player playing the black pieces (that is the black side of the pieces) is called Black. The other player plays the white pieces and is called White. In Reviser the players play different roles. One player will play the 'Setter,' the other will play the 'Jumper.' Setter and Jumper keep their role during the whole game. At his turn, the Setter places one of his pieces on the board. That piece must be in line with one of his pieces so that one or more opponents pieces are between them (without any empty fields between them). These opponents pieces are flipped. This is the same mechanism as in Reversi. At his turn the Jumper must jump with one of his pieces (on the board) over any number of his opponents pieces in a straight line. The opponents pieces he jumped over are flipped. He may continue to jump with that piece if possible. He must not jump over his own pieces or over empty fields.

The game ends if one player is unable to make a legal move. The player with the greater number of his pieces on the board wins the game.

An entry into the About.com: 2002 Unequal Forces Game Design Competition.

Name: Star Fleet Battles: Module G3 – Master Annex File
Description:
From the publisher, Amarillo Design Bureau:

The all-new updated Master Annex file. Includes all of the annexes from the Alpha Octant (except the rarely used and very large #5) plus much more. Master Ship Chart, Master PF Chart, Master Fighter Chart (including mega-fighters), Master Weapons Chart. Compilation of all game charts and tables. All updated through the most recent products and updates with all corrections, additional data, and new features.

Name: Praxis
Description:
Equipment:

* A standard chess set and board
    * 4 pieces that represent the Yin and Yang contained in both teams: one clear stone, one translucent black stone, one opaque white stone, and one opaque black stone

Praxis is a chess variant that incorporates the Zen philosophy of opposing forces defining the Way. Ancient books, such as the I Ching, show the interaction of these two forces, Yin and Yang, and their effect upon human life. Praxis is an attempt to bring these forces into a game that already presents the struggle between opposing forces.

From the game's designer:

'This is a Chess variant I created in college. I uncovered it in a recent basement purge. I scanned it and posted the scans then destroyed the original due to mildew damage. Once you get over the early 90's graphics... it might just be playable!'

Available from http://gnomegaming.com/ourgames

Name: Por'rika
Description:
Por'rika(c) (Sacred Waters) is an old Schelati(c) game. The Schelati are a species of amphibians that have, since the beginning of recorded history, laid their eggs in the Sacred Waters. These Sacred Waters, however, happened to be located in the prime hunting territory for the Ser'ra(c), large birds of prey that were the Schelati's only natural enemy. The game is based on this conflict.

The object of the copper side is to get both Egg-Carriers into the Scared Water spaces. The object of the silver side is to stop that from happening.

An entry into the About.com: 2002 Unequal Forces Game Design Competition.

Name: Federation Commander: Reference Rulebook
Description: Federation Commander: Reference Rulebook (officially the fifth edition of the Federation Commander rules) contains all the rules from Klingon Border, Klingon Attack, Romulan Border, Romulan Attack, Tholian Attack, Booster Zero, Battleships Attack, Distant Kingdoms, Orion Attack, and War and Peace, as well as those from the free monthly Communique newsletter and the semiannual Captain's Log magazine. This book includes all corrections, revisions, and updates to date. It is not a standalone product and contains only rules (no game components).

Name: Poker Squares
Description:
Summary: Place 25 cards sequentially in a 5-by-5 grid with an object to score the highest Poker combinations in each row and column.

Equipment: 

     a shuffled standard (French) 52-card deck
     a pen and Poker Squares grid for each player


Rules:  Each turn, a card is drawn from the deck and announced.  Each player must then privately write the card rank and suit (e.g. “10C” for 10 of Clubs, “AH” for Ace of Hearts) in any empty cell of their 5-by-5 grid.  Once written in the grid, cards may not be moved.  After all players have written the card, the next turn begins.  When player grids are full after 25 cards, grids are scored.
  
Scoring:  The 5-card hand of each grid row and column is scored according to a point system.





 Poker Squares Hand Scoring Systems

    
         Poker Hand 
         American Points 
         English Points

    
    
         Royal Flush 
         100 
         30

    
    
         Straight Flush 
         75 
         30

    
    
         Four of a Kind 
         50 
         16

    
    
         Full House 
         25 
         10

    
    
         Flush 
         20 
         5

    
    
         Straight 
         15 
         12

    
    
         Three of a Kind 
         10 
         6

    
    
         Two Pair 
         5 
         2

    
    
         One Pair 
         2 
         1

    
    
         High Card 
         0 
         0

    


A player's total score is the sum of the hand scores for each of the 10 row and column hands.

Name: Pipelayer
Description:
Pipelayer is a game played with two grids of dots that are slightly offset from one another. The long dimension should be one longer than the short dimension.

The players take turns moving by connecting two dots. A player can only connect dots that are adjacent horizontally or vertically and also only dots of his own color. No move may draw across another move. To win a player must make a continuous connection from one side of the board to the other in the long direction for his color of dots.

An animated example is available on the game's website.

Name: Package War!
Description:
Equipment: Package War! requires a minimum of 16 six-sided dice, and pencil and paper for noting points scored. 26 six-sided dice are recommended.

Package War! is a two player game where each player takes on the role of a package shipping mogul determined to dominate the industry and crush the competition. In this cut-throat game, each shipping magnate tries to foil the competition by crushing their packages and stacking their own packages as high as they can. Be the first to dominate the package shipping industry!

An entry into the About.com: 2004 Shared Pieces Game Design Competition.

Name: Kunskap på tvärs
Description:
Answer science questions and move around the board in the hunt for the questions that give you points. Guess the year of an event and the closer to the year you get, the more points you earn.
The playing pieces are famous scientists like Einstein and Pasteur.
Like in Trivial Pursuit knowledge is the most important factor in deciding the winner.

Name: Reality Show
Description:
Reality Show is an nontraditional 'soft' psychological party game. The players carry out lot of activities. The basic system of the game can be divided in two parts: covering frame and the game tasks.

Covering frame: is inspired by TV reality shows. Players represent imaginary persons who are part of an imaginary TV reality show. Their lives are filmed by cameras... In this frame players develop their identities while entering into the world of plots, strategies and psychology. After a certain time some players fall out (he/she can't try to gain the main award) and he/she continues as a 'passive' player (who is supposed to be noticeably active).

Tasks of play: is a collection of cards with more than 60 tasks and the center of the game. Most tasks have a certain psychological background. But this psychological element is rather only an additional dimension of tasks and it isn't necessary for players to mark it. Players draw one task card in each round, they read a setting and a certain numbers of players will be able to register to the task. If the task is carried out he/she will get a number of votes (this number of supposed votes is chosen by each player himself/herself before carrying out the task). Players can carry out about 16 tasks in each game.

Name: Balanstorn
Description:
This is a childrens game. Put the tower together, choose your color on your players. Roll the dice and put one of your player on the same color level the dice showing. If the tower falls you have lost this game.

Contents:
24 color figures
1 dice
1 tower

Name: Tiny Toon Adventures
Description: All people that like Siri and Sigge Spratt (Buster & Babs Bunny) have hidden at the Looniversitetet (ACME Looniversity) and your job is to find them. Your friends are on 20 tiles and the person who find the most friends of the same color wins this game. But be aware: Siris and Sigges enemies have also hid and will give you some trouble if you find them instead.

Name: Piecepack Fan Tan
Description: This is a piecepack port. Fan Tan is believed to have been invented by Kwan Chung, a renowned statesmen of antiquity who died in 645BC. There is a likelihood that the game was invented for soldiers as a way for them to pass the time in camp. The name means spreading out, as the real life version involves spreading out coins or buttons in groups of four until there is a remainder of none to three. San Francisco's large chinese community had dozens of Fan Tan Houses in the 19th century. Fan tan is still played at Macau casinos, where play goes on day and night, every day of the week, and bets can be made from 5 cents to 500 dollars.

Name: Flickago
Description:
Three Inspectors have come to Chicago, and your gang wants to make sure they don't get any information about the family. The same thought has occurred to your nemesis, and you've both gathered your family and those loyal to you, ready for a fight.

Flickago is a flicking game where each player is trying to keep their gang members in the other gang's turf in order to keep the inspectors -out- of their home turf.

There's more strategy than just flicking hard, and plenty of decisions.

Name: Zest
Description:
This is a gin-rummy-type word card game, whose object is to be the first to clear your hand.

The deck has 54 cards, two of each letter and two wild cards.  Players are dealt 9 cards each for 2, 3 or 4 players, 8 each for 5, and 7 each for 6.  In a turn, a player draws one card from the draw or discard pile, lays down a word or adds to an existing word, and discards one.

The first player to go out gets one point per card in everyone else's hands; if the draw pile runs out the hand ends and the player with fewest cards wins the points.  The game is won at 25 points.  If a players spells "zest" without wild cards, he gets 25 points and wins immediately.

Name: Doblo
Description: In this dice rolling game, players try to make a connection of three, four and five. The roll of the die determines what character should be filled in on the scoring form: X,0 or -. You can only win this game with a little luck of the die and a lot of strategic thinking.

Name: Witt
Description:
This word card game has the uncommon feature that each card has two letters on it -- either one can be used to make a word.  (They are in opposite corners, but in each corner you see one letter, its value, and the letter in the opposite corner.)  Of the 105 cards, 8 of them have a are wild cards in one corner, and four are wild on both ends.

Each player is dealt 8 cards, and the top card of the draw pile is used to start the discard pile.  In a turn, a player makes a word starting with either letter of the top discard, and using cards from his hand for the rest.  The letters' values -- ranging from 2 to 20 -- are added for the word's score, which is added to the player's total.  The word is then discarded, the player fills out their hand back to 8 from the draw pile, and the next player takes a turn, using the new top discard to start a word.

Players pass if they cannot make a word from their hand.  The game ends when every player passes in turn, typically after the draw pile is exhausted.  The lower value of each card in hand is subtracted from the players' scores, and the highest total wins.  Optional rules allow bonus points for long words.

Name: Roaches!
Description:
A Skin-crawling card game for 3-6 players.

You have an infestation problem and the only way to deal with it is to give it to someone else!

In Roaches! all players begin with a hand of cards representing their roach infestation.  By forming pairs they may discard these cards either to other players or to a central pile on the table.  By playing your cards on an opponent you can keep them from returning the favour, but by playing to the pile you can draw a special event card which may have the power to change the game ... because at any time you might just get stuck with every roach on the table!

This game is free for download at http://kenmgames.wordpress.com

Name: Spellbound
Description:
This word card game has 108 cards, most with a letter and value (1-9), except for two wild cards with value zero.

Each player is dealt 10 cards.  In their turn, a player may: form a new word from their hand; add from their hand to either end of a word already on the table; discard any number of their cards to the bottom of the draw pile; or pass.  If they played or added to a word, they score all points in the word, then draw back up to 10.  If a wild card is on the table, and they have a card for the letter it stands for, they may swap it for the wild card, at the start of their turn.

Play ends when the draw pile is exhausted and one player exhausts his hand or everyone passes in turn.  The values of the cards in hand are subtracted from the scores, and the highest wins.

Name: Pub Quiz
Description:
Fancy yourself as a trivia king or queen? Find out who the brainiest bar-flies are as you enjoy a traditional pub quiz - in the comfort of your home.

If you're a quiz whiz then this is the game for you. Great general knowledge and quick thinking are what counts here, and if you and your fellow players want to be crowned pub champs, then team work is a must! Be ready to notch up points in the quick fire rounds then blast the opposition in 2 blistering bonus heats. So get your thinking caps on - and the drinks in!

Name: Roll Dice Kill Monsters Have Fun Dungeon Crawler
Description: ROLL DICE KILL MONSTERS HAVE FUN DUNGEON CRAWLER is a fresh take on mazes, this game is more than just finding a path from start to finish, it's also about overcoming the obstacles along the way. The obstacles come in the form of traps and adversaries. The traps are whatever the players imagine them to be they could be a pit of spikes, a falling boulder, etc. The adversaries are met by the players by means of a random encounter system, defeating adversaries will most certainly garner usable rewards for the players. In ROLL DICE KILL MONSTERS HAVE FUN DUNGEON CRAWLER there are two kinds of mazes. The first is to successfully reach the finish from a set start point. The second is to successfully meet and defeat a boss type character. ROLL DICE KILL MONSTERS HAVE FUN DUNGEON CRAWLER is the groundbreaking amalgamation of a board game and an analog role playing game, without any of the convoluted aspects of analog role playing games.

Name: Starship Shootouts
Description:
A tactical science fiction ship combat game played on a hex map. Fleets are created by allocating build points and designing ships. Different races have unique weapons and other characteristics.

The entire game comes in a 3" x 5" ziplock bag. The rule book is 2.5" x 3.5" and has 30 pages. A folded hex map (8" x 9") with tiny 1/4" hexes is included and has ship templates for all 6 races on the opposite side. Includes two d6 dice, each 0.50cm on a side.

Originally costing $1, this may be the smallest wargame ever produced!

Name: Starships and Solar Systems
Description:
A campaign game supplement for Starship Shootouts played on a hex map. Exploration discovers worlds which are then developed to produce build points which are used to build ships and bases. Rules for designing bases and new ship types (fighters and carriers) are included. Combat is resolved using Starship Shootouts with additional rules for attacking worlds.

The entire game comes in a 3" x 5" ziplock bag. The rule book is 2.5" x 3.5" and has 30 pages. A folded hex star map (5" x 8") with tiny 1/4" hexes is included and has templates for game counters on the opposite side.

Originally costing 50 cents, this may be the smallest game supplement ever produced!

Name: Starpower: Tactical Ship Combat in the 29th Century
Description:
Subtitled: Tactical Ship Combat in the 29th Century, Starpower is the first game in the "Four Empires Series". It is a tactical science fiction miniatures game played on a large surface. It uses pre-written orders for each turn. There are minimal special abilities for the four "empires".

The game ships in a ziplock bag including a 32-page rulebook with advanced and optional rules, information on the four empires, and fleet compositions. Also included are reproducible ship miniatures and status sheets, an order sheet, a boarding template, tables, and counters for boarding parties and small craft.

Name: Fast and Dirty
Description:
Fast and Dirty was designed to provide a quick, uncomplicated, yet realistic game system for small unit modern day, near future and sci-fi skirmish combat.

By building upon basic military principles that have not changed much over time, such as troop morale, motivation, and experience, these rules are an attempt to create a system that will serve just as well for fire fights today as those far off into the future.

Each player will field a small force, ranging from a few squads to a reinforced platoon with support elements, including heavy weapons, artillery, even a vehicle or two. Forces can be created in one of three ways: using a simple random force generation system to get you playing quickly, a more advanced system for experienced players, and a detailed points system for the ultimate in flexibility. Though the system is easy to learn and play, this doesn’t mean the game is lacking details.

In fact, there are actually three levels of play. First you will learn the Basic Game, which provides all the core rules necessary to head off into battle. Then, as you become familiar with the system, you might want to consider using some of the Advanced Rules, which will add more depth to your gaming experience. Finally, there are a number of Optional Rules which you can incorporate into your games to add even greater detail. The choice is yours.

Fast and Dirty is a generic system, specifically designed to work with a wide array of settings and miniatures. Feel free to devise your own worlds and forces, based upon the miniatures in your collection.

Name: Schneewittchen-Spiel
Description: A dice rolling game for smaller children. The players lay out cards (face down) and roll dice to move Snowwhite, a prince and a witch along the card path. A card on which a movement ends is turned face up. Witch or Snowwhite/prince can win by reaching the dwarves' house first, but only if they have picked up certain cards along the way.

Name: Uppgjörið
Description: A game based on the game Guillotine, where players get cards with actions and persons somehow connected to the Bank Crisis in Iceland, whether they be politicians, business-men, tv personalities and so on. Players play their cards (one person and one action card each round) and try to get the 25 points needed to win.

Name: 70 mínútur
Description: A game based on the tv show 70 mínútur (70 minutes). Players move along the 70 spaces on the track and have to answer questions, do silly things (called challenges) or drink the Disgusting Drink (the ingredients being various substances blended as the game progresses).

Name: Fast Action Hockey
Description:
Fast Action Hockey (DMC Games) is an exciting statistical simulation board game that lets you replay the NHL championships--or the entire 2000-2001 season--solitaire, or in head-to-head competition with a friend. Over 650 individually rated players representing all 30 teams are yours to command.

Fast Action Hockey plays quickly because it focuses on the "fun stuff"--shooting and scoring--while eliminating time-consuming elements that add little or nothing to the excitement such as face-offs, puck passing, penalties, line changes, time-clock tracking, etc. What makes FAH even better is the ease and quickness of play. You won’t have to spend an hour or two playing a single game. Instead, once you are familiar with the play sequence and the charts, you can play a game in 20 minutes or less, and easily replay the entire Stanley Cup finals in one evening!

Basic Sequence of Play

There are three phases to FAH:

1) Select 18 players and 1 goaltender from each team and list them on the score sheet.

2) Determine the number of shots each player will take during the game and write down in the "SOG" column of the scoresheet.  To do this, check for the player’s shots grade ("Sh" on the roster sheet), roll all 3 dice and consult the "Player Shots" chart.

3) Resolve the shots for each player (i.e., determine the outcome of each player’s shots on goal.) and assign assists (the number of assists for each goal is indicated on the goal scoring chart).

Fast Action Hockey will produce lifelike statistical performances over the course of an entire replay season when playing schedules similar to the actual.

(Game was marketed on a limited scale in 2001 only, and sold primarily through Ebay).

Name: Frostbitten!
Description:
A new "Ice Age" has struck the planet! 
Ice floes are circling the oceans, allowing Antarctic penguins to drift into the territory of Arctic polar bears. 
Get your penguins safely from the South Pole to the North Pole across drifting ice floes whilst watching out for a hungry Polar Bear. 
This is a piecepack port of Milton-Bradley’s "Polar Dare!"
